718636f-a.text:
Charlton Street in Greenwich Village looking east from Varick Street towards McDougals Alley. The horsecar was one of those on the crosstown line from the Chambers Street Ferry to Ave. C and
11th Street.
Date: 1908
Source: Unknown
718636f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718641f-a.text:
(1)
61 to 75 Charlton Street, north side, between Varick and Hudson Streets; the view is towards Hudson Street. No. 59, with the awning out, is partly included at the right. No. 67, the house with the flat roof, has only a facing of brick, its frame sides are visible.
Nos. 71 and 73 are also frame houses.
1912.
(2)
The same, looking towards Varick Street. 75 Charlton Street adjoins the vacant lot at the left. 75-73 and 71-69 are practically pairs in appearance, but Nos. 73 and 71 are frame buildings with
only a facing of brick.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
718641f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723758f-a.text:
172, 176 Varick Street and 53 Charlton Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner. These buildings will be demolished, along with the entire east side of Varick Street, in the subway construction and
widening of Varick Street in 1914.
About 1912.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
723758f-a.folder: Varick Street & Charlton Street, Manhattan, NY

718637f-a.text:
32 to 16 Charlton Street, a row of fine old houses on the south
side, between Varick and MacDougal Streets.
About 1918.
New York Sun staff photograph.
Cift of E. M. Jenks.
718637f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718639f.text:
39 Charlton Street, north side, east of Varick Street, showing the fine old Georgian doorway of the former Stivers home.
About 1918.
New York Sun staff photograph.
nift of E. M. Jenks.
718639f.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718640f-a.text:
Charlton Street, east from No. 46, south side, and No. 43, north side, east of Varick Street, towards the eastern end of Charlton Street at MacDougal Street, where Charlton Street meets the western end of Prince Street. At the right may be seen the Charlton Momorial Church, No. 40-34 Charlton Street. The five-story stable, at No.
14-12 Charlton Street, will shortly become a garage.
About 1918.
New York Sun staff photograph.
Cift of E. M. Jenks.
Nle; N RO6G0
718640f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718638f-a.text:
37, 39 Charlton Street, north side, east of Varick Street, two of the fine old houses for which this street is known.
About 1920.
0ift of E. M. Jenks.
718638f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718643f-a.text:
66-64, 62-60, 58 Charlton Street, adjoining and at the S.W. corner of varick Street. The little corner house is of brick, and looks as if it had been a saloon. The others are frame with brick facing. Around 1930 Nos. 58 to 62 will be replaced by a six-story garage.
About 1925.
718643f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723761f-a.text:
179, 181 Varick Street (rear view), west side, between Charlton
and King Streets.
March 9, 1926.
Underwood & Underwood.

723762f-a.text:
179, 181 Varick Street (side and rear view), west side, between
Charlton and King Streets.
March 5, 1926.
Underwood &. Underwood.
723762f-a.folder: Varick Street & Charlton Street, Manhattan, NY

723763f-a.text:
179, 181 Varick Street, west side, between Charlton and King Streets. A loft building is to be erected between No. 179 and the N.W. corner of Charlton Street. These two houses Will be torn down
about 1931 and replaced by a Stewart's Cafeteria.
February 11, 1926.
ITnnderwood & Underwood.
723763f-a.folder: Varick Street & Charlton Street, Manhattan, NY

723759f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, from Charlton to King Streets. In 1914 the entire east side of Varick Street was ripped out and the west side Interborough subway dug. At that time all the houses facing Varick Street in this block were demolished. The house at the N.E. corner of Charlton Street is 53 Charlton, merged with No. 51 and remodelled. The tenement house at the north end of the block is No. 60 King Street. Since 1921 the little one-story shops shown here have been built to fill in the vacant space along between these two buildings and along Varick Street.

Late in 1929 all these houses will come out, when work begins on the Greybar-Varick Building.

February 12, 1928
P.L. Sperr.
723759f-a.folder: Varick Street & Charlton Street, Manhattan, NY

718645f-a.text:
Charlton Street, north side, east from and including No. 4 adjoining the Greybar-Varick Building (1930) at the N.E. corne Varick Street. The cross at the right marks the Charlton Stre Memorial Church, 40-34 Charlton Street; since 1930 its name ha changed to Bethlehem Memorial Presbyterian Church.
May 19, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
718645f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

718642f-a.text:
Charlton Street, north side, east from No. 65, west of Varick Street, to the eastern end of Charlton Street at MacDougal and Prince Streets. The old houses 65 to 57, adjoining and at the N.W. corner, were demolished in January 1926. The Greybar-Varick Building, across the way on the east side of Varick Street, shown nearing completion, took out Nos. 53-45 Charlton Street, inclusive.
In the middle of the street, in front of about No. 35, is the site of the Richmond Hill house, where Presidents Washington and Adams both lived, and which was the house of Aaron Burr at the time he shot Alexander Hamilton. Charlton Street was originally called Betty Street or Burr Street, but received its present name in 1807.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr
718642f-a.folder: Charlton Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

Charlton Street, north side, east from No. 65, west of Varick Street, to the eastern end of Charlton Street at MacDougal and Prince Streets. The Greybar-Varick Building, across the way on the east side of Varick Street, shown nearing completion, took out Nos. 53-45 Charlton Street, inclusive.
In the middle of the street, in front of about No. 35, is the site of the Richmond Hill house, where Presidents Washington and Adams both lived, and which was the house of Aaron Burr at the time he shot Alexander Hamilton. Charlton Street was originally called Betty Street or Burr Street, but received its present name in 1807.

P. L. Sperr

64 Charlton Street, adjoining the S.W. corner of Varick Street.
Only a part of No. 66, next door, is shown.

723760f-a.text:
179 Varick Street (south wall), west side, between Charlton and King Streets. Nos. 171 to 177 have been demolished for the erection
of a ten-story loft building.
February 11, 1926.
Underwood & Underwood.
